comments.commentBody:
You left out "wars that punish". Try discussing it sometime in a column.

"Carthage delenda est"

I noticed this diminution of math skills in my father around age 80. An engineer by training and vocation, I asked him to help my daughter with her 8th-grade math homework while they were visiting. She has special needs and usually needed a bit of a tutorial or even complete reteaching before or during the completion of homework every night. She was working some tricky percentage problems, but I figured they would be simple for him. Later that night, when I happened to check her work, I found that they'd done all the problems wrong, and she and I had to redo them.

I was happy to note that she did not judge her grandfather for his confusion (I suspect others made the same mistakes on that homework!). But it was a valuable wake up call for me, and I informed my brothers who were in better proximity to help the folks day to day.
How do you see a scoreboard? Or where? Not that I will ever be on it!

.
It's on the main Puzzles Page (nytimes.com/crosswords/index)! I don't know if it's visible for people who use other apps to do the puzzle, but for people who use the ______ software on nytimes.com (don't know the name, often just call it "Howard"), it displays rudimentary stats for day, week, and month ONLY for XWPs completed without using Check or Reveal.

I know this is not very thorough of an explanation ... I access everything Puzzle via that main Puzzle page, incl. XWPs, blog, variety puzzles, etc. Do not have any device besides a computer, so I just use nytimes.com's own XWP software.

MTFT,
And don't call me Churlish!

.
.
Learned something about the software today when my computer signalled something was amiss.

I paused the XWP (nearly complete anyway) to see if something was actually wrong; dealt with whatever it was; and later unpaused the XWP. So the timeclock started running from the pause point, and gave me my solve time when I finished 6 mins later (roughly the same as my Saturday solve time).

But my solve time was not entered in the solve-time scoreboard (not that I would've placed in the top 500 anyway). I am convinced that this resulted from my use of PAUSE, although it could have resulted from whatever weirdness my computer was enduring.

Will try not to be churlish about it.

Anyway, I always cherish Patrick Berry's offerings.

I tried to download a couple his puzzles once, without paying, because I'm cheapish.
Not hanged. We should never sink to their depths.

Robert, how are drone strikes murder any more than aerial bombardment or any other form of warfare? War is about killing people. I don't see that the method used to accomplish it makes it any worse. You're equally dead whether you're killed by a drone or an M-16.
What is the name of the war which has been declared in Yemen or Pakistan by act of  Congress?

Over 100 incident children have been killed but they didn't get a apology because oh yeah they are from Yemen and Pakistan not American.Now every one is questioning Drone strikes just because two Americans got killed.
Brilliant puzzle. Absolutely loved it!

"Drone on" may be Stu Freeman's best pun ever!
Drones are no smarter than doorbells. It's the ringer who counts.
My pun.

Ex Machina isn't a "sci-fi thriller" so much as a sci-fi snooze.  It asks some questions that are worth thinking about (some of which were previously posed in movies like "Blade Runner" and "A.I." as well as in the recent "Chappie") but it prefers to drone on and on without ever managing a frisson of tension or dread.  Blah!

Whether you support it or not, the program does not fit the definition of terrorism.

The concept of battlefields is meaningless when fighting terrorists, for whom the battlefield is a shopping mall or a civilian aircraft, and who attack from hidey holes in the civilian population. The best one can do in dealing with such creatures is attempt to minimize civilian casualties.

Finally, last I checked, the people being killed were white. Perhaps you mean that they aren't of mostly European descent? In any case, I had to laugh at your assertion of bigotry given that the Al Qaeda terrorists are on s sworn mission to kill American civilians, black, white, green, or grey.

Bill, racist and imperialist? Where, exactly, is this other race? And where, exactly, is the empire? You certainly do like to throw unflattering words around! Why do you think that describing something inaccurately will convince anyone except the fellow travelers, who are already convinced, as they share your ideological assumptions?

My sentiments exactly.  Also, let us remember that this "smart" form of warfare will come back to haunt its innovators when other nations and groups decide they can use drones to kill whom they wish from a safe distance.

The drone program is state terrorism by the US government against the people of Pakistan, Yemen, Somalia and Afghanistan. All are places where people are slaughtered far from battlefields on--at best--questionable justification.

The deaths of the two hostages shows, again, the grotesque chauvinism and racism that only values Western lives (read white) while throwing entire countries into chaos.
Just wonderful our most FAVOURITE of our Four Harosets this year and last

hen3ry,

I have been reading your comments for a while now, and I just want to say I appreciate your insights and humaneness. You're a good person. From what I've read, you've lived through a lot, and relating your experience is a powerful source of connection to meaningful ideas. As pointless as participating in these comment sections can seem, I just want you to know I do appreciate your voice here. You're posts have made a difference to me.

Sincerely,

Jay

Fact: most black males have jobs. If the others availed themselves of free education during youth instead of hustling, stealing, and evading child support, then there would be no problem of huge numbers of black men in jail. Black women don't have this problem because they accept education.
Thank you so much for this comment. All of the "It's their own fault" responses to this devastating Black incarceration drive me into depression. Nice to read some sanity and some humanity.

Is this a remnant of slavery? Is it a signal that the United States has still to accept black people as an integral part of society without feeling threatened by them? We keep on blaming them for our reactions. We tell them to act more like us rather than putting ourselves in their shoes and trying to understand why a black man might run from the police. The idea that if he's innocent he shouldn't run doesn't allow for the fact that his innocence has probably been in doubt from the minute he came into contact with white people. I've seen how white people react to black people in quite a few situations. To expect blacks to view us as trustworthy we have to be trustworthy from day 1, not from the time they become legal adults. We can continue to say it's all their fault but it's not.

I do have some small amount of insight into what goes on because I have a handicapped brother whom others often deliberately misunderstand. He's expected to behave while others can break rules, treat him with complete disrespect, lie about him, and so on. He's guilty because he's handicapped. It makes no sense but that's how it is. The same people who treat him like garbage would scream bloody murder if they were treated the same way. No one should be treated like trash based upon the color of their skin. As King said, they should be judged on the content of their character. And they should also not be treated as guilty because of being black in America.
Make this at least once a week.. Use turkey thigh meat as well. Very delicious

.
Please ignore Paragraphs 1, 2, and 3. Problem must have been in my computer. I re-opened the XWP, moved the cursor around, and exited. Upon returning to the "scoreboard", which shows me how very many people solved the XWP quicker than I, my actual solve time was displayed. It is actually faster than my Saturday XWP solve time, apparently.

I like the separation of love and approval (but, note the but, and I have one, too).

Without good behavior and positive contributions to society, people who don't love them won't want them around, One of the lessons our children need to learn from their parents is that although we love them unconditionally and unreasoning passion, the rest of the world doesn't.

I think there are some problems with the Brooks column and his philosophy. I get that he's trying to talk about a fringe type of parent who pushes and pushes and showers children with his/her disappointment. But he seems to be trying to widen and generalize.

My love isn't conditional, but my approval is. If children don't learn good behavior, manners and respect for others, the world won't love them. It's part of parenting to teach them what the limits are and what positive behavior is. So yes I am going to frown if my child does something wrong. A parent applying unconditional approval to bad behavior creates a child no one wants to experience, and it does the child a disservice. I guess where the unconditional love comes in is that I am forgiving and understanding when they make a mistake. The process takes a long time, and perfect behavior isn't possible or expected.

I am curioous--- do the data permit an answer to a secondary question:  is part of the transformative effect  physical attendance in a college building with a group of students and a professor presiding?   I think the physical commitment is a real component, and I think parts of this article and many of the responses suggest agreement.

I'm a Lutheran pastor whose clinical pastoral education site (a hospital in Chicago) pioneered regular role playing sessions between chaplaincy (interfaith), psychology, and medicine. I was involved only once in a role play; the circumstance was a doctor informing a family of the death of a loved one. The medical doc in my group assigned to deliver the news was awkward and uncomfortable, and the role play allowed a wonderful conversation to open around how to handle death and dying more easily in the hospital. This kind of inter-disciplinary dialogue could also contribute to an overall environment where issues of death and dying are not so taboo.
Very useful recipe to have for unexpected guests. I have made this with a variety of different smoked fishes. Always pleases

really? everyone benefits? Including the troubled teen who thinks it would be cool to have his genitals amputated so he can become a woman? Really? Someone should tell him: you will not be a woman, but rather a man with amputated genitals. Plastic surgery is not the answer to your issues.
Made this often on a barbecue and in my oven..always great

If you could never wear make up or nail polish or jewelry or let anyone know you were a woman,  you might feel differently. Just as many of us as adolescent girls and young women went through a period of wearing too much make-up or trying different fads, so do emerging transwomen. It can take time to find one's personal style and break free of social dictates of what women and girls should be like. For those who have never been able to express their femininity or who are not yet fully confident of appearing feminine enough, it could be such markers help them be viewed by others as female more often. It seems just as oppressive to me to be told these trappings are bad as it is to be told they're necessary or good. I say let each woman appear as she likes and let the rest of society quit harping about it.

Judging by your use of the phrase "Good heavens" should I assume that you are a "crotchety" Boomer? No! Apparently, in this day & age, you should never assume anything. If it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck maybe it's a squirrel.
My dear Conor, your lack of basic anatomy and physiology is unfortunate. You need a diagram.
Don't forget menopause.

You can't ignore these people unless you live like an ostrich.

And futhermore, have the intelligence to zip your own lips. Last I remember, this is an opinion board and you are not the judge of whose opinion is valid or not.
I didn't see the show, but I can't help but imagine the reference to nail polish was a wry metaphor for Jenner getting finally to live the identity she wants to, no?

I feel a great deal of compassion for Mr. Jenner and have a better understanding of the complex issue of being a transgender person thanks to Mr. Jenner's honesty and willingness to confront this issue in such a public way.  His revelation can only help people who are transgender and their families find the love, support and understanding of the issues involved.

Jenner made a personal choice, he should own it and stop living in denial, his tears show him to be unhappy with his choice. Deal with it Bruce, you don't seem happy about your transition but publically weepy.

Billy Martin used to weep in public, he was prickly and combative but a man who took responsibility for his kids as a man.
